oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Discussion - Ray Charles and the album Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music - 2006-03-11
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Discussion about Ray Charles' album Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on March 11, 2006. In support of the exhibit I Can’t Stop Loving You: Ray Charles and Country Music.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Joe Adams; Gerald Wilson; Vince Gill;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Recording begins in progress. Opening comments by Michael Gray. Introductions of panelists. Includes questions from the audience. Subjects include; Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music album -- Gerald Wilson discusses his early relationship with Joe Adams -- Wilson working as an arranger with Ray Charles on the album -- Wilson hearing the Grand Ole Opry as a child in Mississippi -- Joe Adams talks about his history with Ray and the circumstances and time period of the recording of the album -- Gerald Wilson talks about Joe Adams -- Vince Gill talks about Ray Charles' influence on music -- Adams talks about the record company resistance to releasing a Ray Charles country album and why Charles wanted to do the album -- Ray's favorite song from the album --

Charles' interactions with Nashville in the years following the release of the album -- Question regarding the sound of the album and the size of the recording studio -- Musical arrangements using what Wilson calls modern chords and changes -- Closing comments.
